case_vignette:
A 29-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 30 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of severe right-sided back pain for the last hour. The pain is colicky and radiates to the right groin. The patient also reports nausea and pain with urination. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated and the patient reports that she has been following up with her gynecologist on a regular basis. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Examination of the back shows costovertebral angle tenderness on the right side. Laboratory studies show:
Urine
Protein negative
RBC casts negative
RBC 5–7/hpf
WBC casts negative
WBC 1–2/hpf
" (From "Pregnancy-Associated Kidney Disease" by Dr. David A. Schwartz, Medscape, 2011)
Rewritten text:
A 29-year-old patient, gravida 2, para 1, at 30 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of severe right-sided back pain for the last hour. The pain is colicky and radiates to the right groin. The patient also reports nausea and pain with urination. Pregnancy has been uncomplicated and the patient reports that they have been following up with their healthcare provider on a regular basis. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. They do not smoke or drink alcohol. Medications include folic acid and a multivitamin. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Examination of the back shows costovertebral angle tenderness on the right side. Laboratory studies show:
Urine
Protein negative
RBC casts negative
RBC 5–7/hpf
WBC casts negative
WBC 1–2/hpf
 (From "Pregnancy-Associated Kidney Disease" by Dr. David A. Schwartz, Medscape, 2011)  The original text contains several gender-specific references, including:
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Renal and Genitourinary System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm experiencing severe right-sided back pain that radiates to my right groin. I also feel nauseous and have pain when I urinate.
Have you noticed any changes in the color or clarity of your urine, like blood or cloudiness?
No, I haven't noticed any changes in the color or clarity of my urine.
Have you had similar symptoms in the past?
No, I have not had similar symptoms in the past.
Do you have any history of kidney stones in your family?
No, there is no family history of kidney stones.
Are you currently taking any medications or supplements?
Yes, I'm currently taking folic acid and a multivitamin.
Final Diagnosis: Ureterolithiasis (kidney stones in the ureter)

The patient denies any changes in the color or clarity of urine and has no prior history of similar symptoms. There is no family history of kidney stones. The patient is currently taking folic acid and a multivitamin.
